XenotypeDef.label: mousekin
XenotypeDef.descriptionShort: A naturally-evolved Mousekin with no major significant genetic modifications.
XenotypeDef.description: Species: Mus sapiens albus ("Wise white mouse") A race of small and agile anthropomorphic mice, readily identified by their large round ears, short-snouted faces, black beady eyes, pink noses, slight overbite, thin scaly tails and white fur. Mousekin adult males can grow up to 100 centimeters tall, while females tend to reach 90 centimeters in height. They have a smaller head-to-body ratio compared with other humanoid races, resembling oversized toddlers with short legs and noticeable hind rumps. The average gestation period is similar to baseline humans, after which an pregnant mother would typically give birth to a single pup; twins, triplets and other multiple births are rare. Variations among individual Mousekin include different head hair color and lengths independent of their white body fur, as well as moustaches and other forms of facial hair for males. While the vast majority of humanoid rodent-like races in the galaxy are the product of deliberate genetic experimentation on baseline humans dating back millenia, it is generally understood that Mousekins are among the very few species that have evolved naturally from their non-sapient mouse ancestors. Barring accidents, injury or disease, a Mousekin’s average life expectancy is 90~100 years; their head hair turns fully grey by around 60 years of age, but no Mousekin will experience baldness.

XenotypeDef.label: Grimalkin
XenotypeDef.descriptionShort: A naturally-evolved Grimalkin with no major significant genetic modifications.
XenotypeDef.description: Species: Felis sapiens atratus ("Wise black cat") A race of large anthropomorphic cats, readily identified by their triangular ears, uniformly dull black fur, yellow slit-pupiled eyes, protruding upper incisors and long bushy tails. Grimalkin adults can grow up to 150 centimeters tall, with males and females possessing visible scrotums and subdued chest mammary glands respectively, while individuals are discerned by subtle variations in head fur swirl or body odor. Their anatomical proportions are roughly similar to domesticated cats from Old Earth, save for additional bulk from body hair and fat. The average gestation period is similar to baseline humans, after which an pregnant mother would typically give birth to a single kitten, but twins, triplets and other multiple births are also possible. While the vast majority of humanoid feline races in the galaxy are the product of deliberate genetic experimentation on baseline humans dating back millenia, it is understood that Grimalkins originated from pet cats abandoned by an Old Earth Asian rump superpower's failed attempt at interstellar colonization; environmental and evolutionary pressures accelerated the species’ rise into sapience within a span of a mere few hundred years. Barring accidents, injury or disease, a Grimalkin’s average life expectancy is 70~80 years; their body fur becomes slightly matted by around over 60 years of age, but no Grimalkin will experience fur loss.
